articles.headline: Why Reams of Intelligence Did Not Thwart the Paris Attacks
articles.snippet: The government faced gaping questions over its failure to thwart a brazen assault on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, as well as a double hostage situation two days later.
articles.abstract: The government faced gaping questions over its failure to thwart a brazen assault on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, as well as a double hostage situation two days later.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The bloody denouement on Friday of two hostage crises at different ends of a traumatized Paris means attention will now shift to the gaping question facing the French government: How did several jihadists — and possibly a larger cell of co-conspirators — manage to evade surveillance and execute a bold attack despite being well known to the country’s police and intelligence services?
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Jim Yardley

articles.headline: From Vertigo to Tinnitus, Ear Ailments Are New Focus for Drugs
articles.snippet: In search of an alternative to hearing aids or implants, some report success in early trials for drugs to improve hearing or silence tinnitus.
articles.abstract: In search of an alternative to hearing aids or implants, some report success in early trials for drugs to improve hearing or silence tinnitus.
articles.lead_paragraph: Driving to a meeting in 2008, Jay Lichter, a venture capitalist, suddenly became so dizzy he had to pull over and call a friend to take him to the emergency room.

articles.headline: The Uphill Push to Save a Bike-Share Pioneer
articles.snippet: A Canadian investor takes a chance on a pace-setting system that lost its way.
articles.abstract: A Canadian investor takes a chance on a pace-setting system that lost its way.
articles.lead_paragraph: The typical origin story for a tech company includes a paper napkin and a garage. But the company that powers the bike-sharing programs in New York, London, Chicago and a dozen other cities started much differently: It began with a municipal parking authority, wound through bankruptcy court and got another shot at corporate viability off the Madagascar coast during the annual hatching of the green sea turtles.

articles.headline: F.B.I. and Justice Dept. Said to Seek Charges for Petraeus
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. and Justice Department prosecutors suggested bringing felony charges against the retired general for providing classified information to his former mistress while he was director of the C.I.A., officials said.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. and Justice Department prosecutors suggested bringing felony charges against the retired general for providing classified information to his former mistress while he was director of the C.I.A., officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. and Justice Department prosecutors have recommended bringing felony charges against David H. Petraeus, contending that he provided classified information to a lover while he was director of the C.I.A., officials said, and leaving Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to decide whether to seek an indictment that could send the pre-eminent military officer of his generation to prison.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Windfall for Taxpayers Coming to an End
articles.snippet: The Fed turns over most of its profits from a bond-buying campaign to the Treasury Department, helping people buy cars and refinance mortgages. But the earnings are set to decrease.
articles.abstract: The Fed turns over most of its profits from a bond-buying campaign to the Treasury Department, helping people buy cars and refinance mortgages. But the earnings are set to decrease.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s bond-buying campaign continues to produce one clear benefit: a windfall for taxpayers.

articles.headline: Economy Up, G.O.P. Wants a Little Credit
articles.snippet: How both parties finesse an economic recovery that is clearly gathering steam will have major ramifications for the coming presidential election cycle.
articles.abstract: How both parties finesse an economic recovery that is clearly gathering steam will have major ramifications for the coming presidential election cycle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After years of finding the dark lining in every silver economic cloud, Republicans are facing a political quandary that is dividing their leadership even as it buoys the nation: The economy appears to be achieving liftoff.

articles.headline: Growing Up on Easy Street Has Its Own Dangers
articles.snippet: An emerging body of research suggests that adolescents in wealthy families are more likely to suffer from depression, anxiety, substance abuse problems and other ailments than their less-well-off peers.
articles.abstract: An emerging body of research suggests that adolescents in wealthy families are more likely to suffer from depression, anxiety, substance abuse problems and other ailments than their less-well-off peers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Thomas Gilbert Jr. was arrested on Monday and charged with killing his wealthy father with a gunshot to the head, the rubbernecking and tut-tutting began almost immediately.

articles.headline: Days of Sirens, Fear and Blood: ‘France Is Turned Upside Down’
articles.snippet: Friday was a day, like the previous two, of violence in and around Paris, one that ended with France unsure whether this drama is now truly over or a predictor of more cultural, religious and political violence to come.
articles.abstract: Friday was a day, like the previous two, of violence in and around Paris, one that ended with France unsure whether this drama is now truly over or a predictor of more cultural, religious and political violence to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was a day of sirens, helicopters in the air, frantic news bulletins; of police cordons and anxious crowds; of young children led away from schools to safety. It was a day, like the previous two, of blood and horror in and around Paris, one that ended with France unsure whether this drama is now truly over or a predictor of more cultural, religious and political violence to come.

articles.headline: French Premier Declares ‘War’ on Radical Islam as Paris Girds for Rally
articles.snippet: Law enforcement officials appealed to the public to help find Hayat Boumeddiene, the girlfriend of Amedy Coulibaly, who took hostages at a kosher supermarket.
articles.abstract: Law enforcement officials appealed to the public to help find Hayat Boumeddiene, the girlfriend of Amedy Coulibaly, who took hostages at a kosher supermarket.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Prime Minister Manuel Valls declared Saturday that France was at war with radical Islam after the harrowing sieges that led to the deaths of three gunmen and four hostages the day before. New details emerged about the bloody final confrontations, and security forces remained on high alert.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Maïa de la Baume

articles.headline: Kicking Dodd-Frank in the Teeth
articles.snippet: New legislation, promoted as making only technical changes in a financial regulation law, could end up gutting some of its provisions.
articles.abstract: New legislation, promoted as making only technical changes in a financial regulation law, could end up gutting some of its provisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 114th Congress has been at work for less than a week, but a goal for many of its members is already evident: a further rollback of regulations put in place to keep markets and Main Street safe from reckless Wall Street practices.

articles.headline: Writing Off the Warhol Next Door
articles.snippet: Wealthy art collectors are benefiting from tax breaks when they build museums with limited public access, often near their homes.
articles.abstract: Wealthy art collectors are benefiting from tax breaks when they build museums with limited public access, often near their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Brant Foundation Art Study Center — a picturesque gallery space inside a converted 1902 stone barn — is just down the road from the Greenwich, Conn., estate of its creator, Peter M. Brant, the newsprint magnate and avid art collector. There are no identifying signs for the center, whether at the turnoff on North Street, at the security gate or on the building itself, though the location is known to the art-world cognoscenti and celebrities who attend the twice-a-year gala openings, held at the private polo club next door that Mr. Brant also founded. Visits to the center itself are by appointment only.

articles.headline: In New Era of Terrorism, Voice From Yemen Echoes
articles.snippet: Anwar al-Awlaki, an American who joined Al Qaeda but was killed by a C.I.A. drone strike in 2011, has remained a leading influence on jihadists, and there is evidence that Yemen’s Al Qaeda branch, and Mr. Awlaki, had a role in preparations for the...
articles.abstract: Anwar al-Awlaki, an American who joined Al Qaeda but was killed by a C.I.A. drone strike in 2011, has remained a leading influence on jihadists, and there is evidence that Yemen’s Al Qaeda branch, and Mr. Awlaki, had a role in preparations for the deadly assault in Paris.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than five years now, as Western terrorism investigators have searched for critical influences behind the latest jihadist plot, one name has surfaced again and again.

articles.headline: For Jeb Bush, Evolving Views Over 2 Decades
articles.snippet: Allies say the former governor of Florida, a possible Republican contender for the presidency in 2016, has tried to present himself as less harsh than in the past.
articles.abstract: Allies say the former governor of Florida, a possible Republican contender for the presidency in 2016, has tried to present himself as less harsh than in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush once called for building prisons and emphasizing “punishment over therapy” for juvenile offenders. Today, he supports reforming the criminal justice system, arguing that incarceration can harden low-level lawbreakers into career criminals.

articles.headline: No Moon Suits, Just Trunks and the Healing Surf
articles.snippet: As Ebola gnaws through Sierra Leone, those at Bureh Beach Surf Club teach and feed tourists, eking out a living seemingly determined to pursue their passion as a way to cope.
articles.abstract: As Ebola gnaws through Sierra Leone, those at Bureh Beach Surf Club teach and feed tourists, eking out a living seemingly determined to pursue their passion as a way to cope.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUREH BEACH, Sierra Leone — There is at least one place in this country, along a quiet, palm-fringed cove, where nobody is talking about viral loads or death rates, treatment centers or protective suits.

articles.headline: Huge Show of Solidarity in Paris Against Terrorism
articles.snippet: More than one million people marched through the French capital with world leaders, who linked arms, in a defiant rally after deadly terrorist attacks.
articles.abstract: More than one million people marched through the French capital with world leaders, who linked arms, in a defiant rally after deadly terrorist attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — More than a million people joined over 40 presidents and prime ministers on the streets of Paris on Sunday in the most striking show of solidarity in the West against the threat of Islamic extremism since the Sept. 11 attacks.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Dan Bilefsky

articles.headline: Deal Makers Invade CES, the Land of Geeks
articles.snippet: The International CES has become a kind of Woodstock for marketers, brands, agencies and media companies.
articles.abstract: The International CES has become a kind of Woodstock for marketers, brands, agencies and media companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: As I walked past the booth staffed by robots selling robots, the plants that water themselves and the prototype Mercedes with no driver at the International CES trade show last week, it occurred to me that the future of human existence might not require many humans.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Turns Its Eye to Education
articles.snippet: Educational technology companies are latecomers to exploiting the potential of the Internet, but venture capitalists seem to believe their time has come.
articles.abstract: Educational technology companies are latecomers to exploiting the potential of the Internet, but venture capitalists seem to believe their time has come.
articles.lead_paragraph: The education technology business is chock-full of fledgling companies whose innovative ideas have not yet proved effective — or profitable. But that is not slowing investors, who are pouring money into ventures as diverse as free classroom-management apps for teachers and foreign language lessons for adult learners.

articles.headline: For Jimmy Lai, Hong Kong’s Rebellious Tycoon, Next Battle May Be in Court
articles.snippet: In the aftermath of democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong, Mr. Lai faces perhaps his greatest test, which could have bigger repercussions for the city.
articles.abstract: In the aftermath of democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong, Mr. Lai faces perhaps his greatest test, which could have bigger repercussions for the city.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Jimmy Lai, Hong Kong’s most fiercely anti-Communist tycoon, calls himself a rebel who likes to make trouble — and he has found no shortage of it.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Governors Face Test in Shift on Ideological Agendas
articles.snippet: Republican governors taking their oaths this month have expressed more muted, less-ideological priorities, but are likely to be challenged by conservative lawmakers.
articles.abstract: Republican governors taking their oaths this month have expressed more muted, less-ideological priorities, but are likely to be challenged by conservative lawmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Four years ago, a wave of new Republican governors administered shock therapy to the states they won, rolling back union rights, approving restrictions on abortion and deeply cutting taxes and spending.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: As Oil Prices Fall, Banks Serving the Energy Industry Brace for a Jolt
articles.snippet: Falling profits on crude oil are likely to leave some companies unable to repay loans, and the banks that have exuberantly extended credit to them may feel the pinch.
articles.abstract: Falling profits on crude oil are likely to leave some companies unable to repay loans, and the banks that have exuberantly extended credit to them may feel the pinch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tumbling oil prices are dimming one of the few big bright spots that banks have enjoyed since the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: In Cold Political Terms, Far Right and French President Both Gain
articles.snippet: After the terrorist attack in France, President François Hollande and the far-right leader Marine Le Pen have seen a boost in popularity, but no one expects the praise to last very long.
articles.abstract: After the terrorist attack in France, President François Hollande and the far-right leader Marine Le Pen have seen a boost in popularity, but no one expects the praise to last very long.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Amid the horrors of the last week, François Hollande is widely judged to have kept his calm, acted decisively and spoken the words of condemnation, defiance and unity expected of a French president, who by tradition is called on to embody the nation.

articles.headline: Aiming to Break Out in a Crowded TV Landscape
articles.snippet: Amid declining ratings and ads, and digital competition, television groups are pouring more resources than ever into developing programs to help them stand out.
articles.abstract: Amid declining ratings and ads, and digital competition, television groups are pouring more resources than ever into developing programs to help them stand out.
articles.lead_paragraph: The demand for original scripted television series is white hot.

articles.headline: Jihadism Born in a Paris Park and Fueled in the Prison Yard
articles.snippet: Members of the group behind last week’s deadly terror attacks became known by the name of a park in a neighborhood that has produced some of Europe’s most militant jihadists.
articles.abstract: Members of the group behind last week’s deadly terror attacks became known by the name of a park in a neighborhood that has produced some of Europe’s most militant jihadists.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — They jogged together or did calisthenics along the hilly lawns and tulip-dotted gardens of Buttes-Chaumont, the public park in northeastern Paris built more than a century ago under Emperor Napoleon III. Or they met in nearby apartments with a janitor turned self-proclaimed imam, a man deemed too radical by one local mosque because of his call for waging jihad in Iraq.

articles.headline: France Deploys Troops to Guard ‘Sensitive Sites’
articles.snippet: The authorities said that they would bolster security to protect potential targets of terrorism, putting in place one of the country’s biggest peacetime security operations.
articles.abstract: The authorities said that they would bolster security to protect potential targets of terrorism, putting in place one of the country’s biggest peacetime security operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Confronting a country in shock from last week’s terrorist attacks, the French government acted on Monday to increase security, sending thousands of soldiers and police officers to guard sites considered vulnerable, including Jewish schools, and calling for measures to reinforce electronic surveillance and curb jihadist recruitment in prisons and other crucibles of radicalization.
articles.byline: By Alan Cowell and Maïa de la Baume

articles.headline: Nominee for Attorney General Less an Activist Than Holder
articles.snippet: Friends say Loretta E. Lynch, an African-American reared in the segregated South, sees herself more as a traditional prosecutor than a civil rights advocate.
articles.abstract: Friends say Loretta E. Lynch, an African-American reared in the segregated South, sees herself more as a traditional prosecutor than a civil rights advocate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While interviewing aspiring prosecutors for jobs in the United States attorney’s office in Brooklyn, Loretta E. Lynch, an African-American Democrat who grew up in the segregated South, often poses a favorite question.
